audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker expressing fascination with Tolkien, stemming from attending his lectures on English at Oxford. He then introduces a conversation between Dennis Gerold and Tolkien about Tolkien's writing, work, and the creation of his epic mythology.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker reflecting on the writing process of *The Hobbit* and expressing that he was caught up in it, much like the character in the book. He elaborates that the characters and story took on a life of their own. The interviewer clarifies whether the speaker was completely under the characters' influence, which the first speaker dismisses, explaining it was more like having a sense that one option out of many must be right and needing to wait to find out which one. This spoken portion is interjected with continuous background static.

The clip features one male speaker who seems to be recalling a story, stating that if you're going to have a complicated story, you must work toward a map; otherwise, you'll never make them happy.  He talks about moons and suns and mentions "1942".  He then says he wrote it in the "30s." After the clip mentions 1949, the speaker states that he "actually wept" and says he had to revise the work. He mentions typing and writing many times on a bed in an attic because he could not afford typing. He says that he's "amusingly" in a position where it does not matter what people think. He then laughs, mentioning that he made mistakes in grammar and that he uses "stowed his past past of dismay."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker questioning a philologist on whether he feels guilt for devoting his life to a fictional thing. The speaker speaks with an inquisitive tone. The philologist responds, claiming that his work has actually done "a great deal of good" and insists that "there is quite a lot of linguistic wisdom". The male interviewer continues with a question regarding the philologist's "fondness" for "comfortable homely things." The philologist responds with apparent amusement, stating that the shire "is very like the kind of world which I first became aware of things" and emphasizes that it "bites into your memory."

A man with a distinguished voice speaks about first Christmas trees and wilting eucalyptus, and how being normally dulled by "heat and zen", one can suddenly find themselves in a quiet Warwickshire village. He mentions a love of "central midland English countryside", good war stones, elden trees, and rustic people. He then discusses arriving in England at one and a half years old, and childhood memories. He mentions how the mind fits new memories onto the old. He recalls a perfectly clear vivid picture of a house and his grandmother's house in Birmingham. He concludes with a memory of bathing in the Indian Ocean at two years old.

The audio clip starts with a conversation between two speakers, likely men, where one describes Frodo as embodying virtues and becoming a Christ figure, while the other responds that he didn't choose a hobbit for this role. The conversational tone is fairly academic. The first speaker continues to discuss the characters' struggles, to which the second speaker responds, indicating more likeliness to the human race.

The audio starts with an older male speaker reflecting on how small people often struggle against "impossible odds". He then discusses the concept of Midgard, clarifying that it isn't necessarily a different planet or a science fiction element, but an old-fashioned term for the world we inhabit, imagined as surrounded by an ocean. The same speaker, continues, further emphasizes this. Finally, there is a sound of acknowledgment with the word "yes".

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing Middle Earth and "this world we live in" but "at a different era". Then, he asks if the author intended for certain races to embody specific principles like "wisdom, craftsmanship, husbandry". Another male voice responds. The audio consists primarily of spoken words.

The audio clip begins with a thoughtful monologue delivered by a male speaker who comments about, “when you've got these people on your hands, you've got to make them different, haven't you?" This is followed by a discussion on the “human race” having “greater power of mind," which he describes as shortening the gap between "conception and the power execution." The speaker mentions "immortality” and longevity as qualities and suggests lifespans "probably last as long as the inhabitability of the earth." He then transitions to describing "dwarves," and remarks that "in many ways they remind you of the Jews," adding "all their words are Semitic," continuing to speak about them as construction beings, then trailing off.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing the physical appearance of resting English people, mentioning that it might reflect the "small reach of their imagination" but not of "their courage or latent power." He identifies this as a strength of a book, noting the "enormous conglomeration of names".

The audio clip presents a conversation between two male speakers. One speaker is discussing how characters don't get lost in his book, as well as his method of story creation by starting with a name and letting it produce the story. He also mentions that Welsh language had a certain influence on the names he chose for mountains and places in his novel. The speaker sounds thoughtful and relaxed. Throughout the dialogue, there are background noises that suggest an indoor setting.

The clip starts with a male speaker acknowledging something with a polite tone, then continuing by stating "very much". After this, the speaker describes being aware of something that is "very potent". A second male voice asks "Is the book to be considered as an allegory?". The first speaker responds with "no".

The clip starts with two speakers engaging in a conversation. One speaker asks about the world declining as the Third Age declines in the speaker's book and asks if the speaker envisions a Fourth Age. The speaker responds that he is exactly the kind of person who's lived through one of the most quickly changing periods of known history, and adds that there's an autumnal quality throughout The Lord of the Rings. He explains that everything is declining and fading toward the end of the Third Age and that every choice tends to upset tradition. The speaker then questions where God is in The Lord of the Rings, and the other speaker says He is mentioned once or twice. A question is posed about whether he is the one. He confirms. He identifies himself as a Roman Catholic. He expresses that he would wish to be remembered chiefly for his writings on philology and other matters, or by The Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit. The speaker says, I should have thought that I, it's a situation to be remembered by The Lord of the Rings. He adds that it would be like being remembered by Longfellow, but they remember Longfellow writes Hiwatha and people forget he was a professor of modern languages.
